title: Modern Windows UI in Win32 desktop applications
body: Bring modern Windows UI to existing Win32, WPF and Windows Forms desktop apps with the option to adopt islands of Windows.UI.Composition and Windows.UI.XAML content incrementally. Allows desktop apps to incrementally adopt UI innovations and creates a bridge to UWP for app UI.

comments.body: I added NavigationView to a WPF app. It is working fine but on high resolution screens the NavigationView control is so tiny and is not usable. Any suggestions? Thanks.
+1, liked it, but with more feature of UWP will be good.
For an update on this issue you can have a look at the following discussion:
I'd like to see the Windows Console display in a UWP UI vice the win32 we currently have. We got tabs for it thanks to Sets. Now let's make it look even better.

I am very much looking forward to having some of our apps use XAML to implement FDS on some of their dialogs. Specifically using Acrylic where a dialog is transient and is summoned by activity in another app (e.g. an Office COM Add-in that summons a dialog from another app).
Bring more modern features to WPF and WinForms. At BUILD 2018 this feature was announced. Please vote and share specific features the community would like the Windows team to build.

There's plenty of situations where one would like a modern UI toolkit but not deal with AppContainers/AppX, but preferably the old school executable and a bunch of resource files. Specifically internal applications in an enterprise (e.g. for an internal SCADA solution).
It seems that Desktop Bridge allow developers to combine win32 code and UWP UI.
Applications that mainly access low level APIs should also look good
This would help bridge the gap between win32 and UWP and make the transition much easier. Please work on this asap!
